Question: Determine the maxima for each relationship: Student-Takes-Course
Reason: Each student can take many courses, and each course has many students, so Student-Takes-Course is many-many.

Question: Determine the maxima for each relationship: City-IsCapitalOf-State
Reason: A city is capital of at most one state, and each state has one capital city. City-IsCapitalOf-State is one-one.

Question: Determine the maxima for each relationship: Airport-Has-Runway
Reason: A runway is located in only one airport. So Airport is singular. An airport can have many runways. So Runway is plural.

Question: Determine the maxima for each relationship: Person-Owns-Vehicle
Reason: A person can own many vehicles and, in most states, a vehicle can have many registered owners. Person-Owns-Vehicle is many-many.

Question: Determine the minima for each relationship: Person-Marries-Person
Reason: Since a person can be unmarried, Person-Marries-Person is zero-zero.

Question: Determine the minima for each relationship: Person-Has-Passport
Reason: Every passport must belong to a person, but not all people have a passport. Person-Has-Passport is one-zero.

Question: Determine the minima for each relationship: Flight-ArrivesAt-Airport
Reason: All flights must arrive at an airport. Assuming the database does not track new or inactive airports, all airports have arriving flights. Flight-ArrivesAt-Airport is one-one.

Question: Determine the maximum and minimum of each attribute: Entity Airport, attribute AirportCode
Reason: Each airport has at most one code, so AirportCode is singular. Every airport has a code, so AirportCode is required.

Question: Determine the maximum and minimum of each attribute: Entity Person, attribute SpouseName
Reason: In most countries, each person has at most one legal spouse, so SpouseName is singular. A person may be unmarried, so SpouseName is optional.

Question: Determine the maximum and minimum of each attribute: Entity Employee, attribute LanguageCode
Reason: An employee may speak several languages, so LanguageCode is plural. Each employee speaks at least one language, so LanguageCode is required.

Question: Cardinality' refers to relationships only.
Reason: Cardinality is a general term for minima and maxima of both relationships and attributes.

Question: In ER diagrams, maxima and minima are drawn for relationships only.
Reason: Minima and maxima for both attributes and relationships can appear in ER diagrams.

Question: Maxima and minima usually depend on business rules.
Reason: Although some maxima and minima are universal, most depend on business rules and are determined during interviews and document review.

Question: In the analysis phase, cardinality is always determined after discovery is complete.
Reason: In principle, discovery precedes determination of cardinality. However, analysis is an iterative process. In practice, cardinality is determined in parallel with discovery, and additional discovery takes place after cardinality is determined.

Question: Each project has at most one code. The ProjectCode attribute is _____.
Reason: Singular' means each entity instance has at most one attribute value. This is the case for ProjectCode, so ProjectCode is singular.

Question: Each project code describes at most one project. The ProjectCode attribute is _____.
Reason: Unique' means each attribute value describes at most one entity instance. This is the case for ProjectCode, so ProjectCode is unique.

Question: A project may have no code. The ProjectCode attribute is _____.
Reason: Optional' means an entity instance may have no attribute value. This is the case for ProjectCode, so ProjectCode is optional.

Question: Distinguishing strong and weak entities is a logical design activity.
Reason: The distinction between strong and weak entities does not depend on a specific database system. Activities that document database requirements without regard to a specific database system are part of the analysis phase.

Question: Determining cardinality always precedes distinguishing strong and weak entities.
Reason: Analysis activities are not always done in sequence. Analysis is iterative and, occasionally, steps are done out of order.

Question: Database designers may look for identifying relationships first, before noting weak entities.
Reason: Some database designers prefer to focus on identifying relationships rather than weak entities.
